description: From a Late Old English (11th century) word dubbian (“to knight by striking with a sword”)  perhaps borrowed from Old French aduber, adober (“equip with arms; adorn”) (also 11th century, Modern French adouber), from Frankish *dubban, from Proto-Germanic *dubjaną (“to fit”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰewbʰ- (“plug, peg, wedge”).
Cognate with Icelandic dubba (dubba til riddara). Compare also drub for an English reflex of the Germanic word.

verbs.description: dub (third-person singular simple present dubs, present participle dubbing, simple past and past participle dubbed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) (now historical) To confer knighthood; the conclusion of the ceremony was marked by a tap on the shoulder with a sword.
(transitive) To name, to entitle, to call. [from the later 16th c]
(transitive) To deem.
To clothe or invest; to ornament; to adorn.

definitionGroups.group: (heading) To strike, rub, or dress smooth; to dab.

entries.meaning: To dress with an adze.
examples: to dub a stick of timber smooth

entries.meaning: To strike cloth with teasels to raise a nap.
To rub or dress with grease, as leather in the process of currying it.
examples: When the skin is thoroughly cleansed, and while yet in its wet and distended state, the process of stuffing, or dubbing (probably a corruption of daubing), is performed. Both sides of the skin, but chiefly the flesh side, are smeared or daubed with a mixture of cod-oil and tallow

entries.meaning: To dress a fishing fly.
To prepare (a gamecock) for fighting, by trimming the hackles and cutting off the comb and wattles.
(rare) A blow, thrust, or poke.

verbs.description: dub (third-person singular simple present dubs, present participle dubbing, simple past and past participle dubbed)

entries.meaning: To make a noise by brisk drumbeats.
To do something badly.
(golf) To execute a shot poorly.
(slang, now historical) An unskillful, awkward person. [from the later part of the 19th c]
examples: The miser, a-seeking lost gelt, / The doughboy, awaiting the battle, / May possibly know how I felt / While the long years dragged by as the dealer / As slow as the slowest of dubs, / Stuck out the last helping of tickets / 'Till I lifted—the Bullet of Clubs!

description: From a shortening of the word double.

entries.meaning: (music, countable) A mostly instrumental remix with all or part of the vocals removed.
(music, uncountable) A style of reggae music involving mixing of different audio tracks.
(music, uncountable) A trend in music starting in 2009, in which bass distortion is synced off timing to electronic dance music.
(slang, countable) A piece of graffiti in metallic colour with a thick black outline.
(countable) The replacement of a voice part in a movie or cartoon, particularly with a translation; an instance of dubbing.

verbs.description: dub (third-person singular simple present dubs, present participle dubbing, simple past and past participle dubbed)

entries.meaning: To add sound to film or change audio on film. [from the first half of the 20th c]
To make a copy from an original or master audio tape.
To replace the original soundtrack of a film with a synchronized translation
To mix audio tracks to produce a new sound; to remix.

description: From Celtic; compare Irish dobhar (“water”), Welsh dŵr (“water”).

entries.meaning: (UK, dialect) A pool or puddle.
(slang) A twenty-dollar sack of marijuana.
(slang) A wheel rim measuring 20 inches or more.

description: From dup (“to open”), from do + up, from Middle English don up (“to open”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete, UK, thieves' cant) A lock.
(obsolete, UK, thieves' cant) A key, especially a master key; a lockpick.

verbs.description: dub (third-person singular simple present dubs, present participle dubbing, simple past and past participle dubbed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, UK, thieves' cant) To open or close.
(video games, Internet slang) A win.
examples: I haven't had a dub in a few games
